diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.reason: SLE can manifest with a wide range of symptoms including arthritis, skin rashes such as malar rash, renal involvement leading to proteinuria, and serositis resulting in pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.reason: While more commonly known for causing joint inflammation and deformity, it can also lead to extra-articular manifestations including skin rashes and pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.reason: Characterized by muscle weakness and a distinctive skin rash, it can also lead to lung and heart involvement.

diagnoses.name: Psoriatic Arthritis
diagnoses.reason: An inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis; patients may exhibit skin rashes including plaques with hyperkeratosis, and less commonly, kidney involvement and pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.reason: This disease presents with features of several connective tissue diseases including lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis leading to symptoms such as rashes, joint pain, and sometimes pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.reason: A multisystem inflammatory disease that can cause skin legions, acute or chronic arthritis, lung and heart involvement, including pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Still's Disease (Adult Onset Still's Disease)
diagnoses.reason: Characterized by fever, arthritis, and a salmon-pink rash; it may also involve organ systems leading to proteinuria and pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.reason: Secondary conditions or infections associated with HIV/AIDS can lead to a variety of symptoms including rashes, renal involvement (proteinuria), and occasionally, pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.reason: Early disseminated Lyme disease can lead to multiple erythema migrans lesions, arthritis, cardiac involvement including pericarditis, and rarely, renal manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Schönlein-Henoch Purpura
diagnoses.reason: An IgA vasculitis affecting small vessels, which can cause a distinctive rash, arthralgia or arthritis, renal involvement including proteinuria, and occasionally gastrointestinal and cardiac involvement.

diagnoses: Schizophrenia (for psychosis differential diagnosis, although non-autoimmune)

diagnoses.name: Vitamin A Deficiency
diagnoses.description: Vitamin A deficiency can manifest as follicular hyperkeratosis and atrophic scarring, primarily due to its role in skin maintenance and repair. While less directly associated, delirium can occur in severe cases due to overall health degradation.

diagnoses.name: Scurvy
diagnoses.description: Scurvy, resulting from vitamin C deficiency, primarily affects the skin, musculoskeletal system, and wound healing processes, creating a potential for follicular hyperkeratosis and atrophic scarring. Joint pain (arthropathy) is also a common symptom.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory condition characterized by muscle weakness and a distinctive skin rash, could theoretically cause atrophic scarring and has been associated with arthropathy. Delirium, however, would be uncommon.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: SLE is an autoimmune disease that can cause a wide range of symptoms, including arthropathy and skin manifestations like hyperkeratosis and scarring. Neuropsychiatric SLE can include symptoms of delirium.

diagnoses.name: Sjogren’s Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder primarily affecting moisture-producing glands. Extra-glandular manifestations may include skin symptoms like hyperkeratosis and systemic features such as arthropathy. Central nervous system involvement might lead to symptoms like delirium.

diagnoses.name: Psoriasis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune skin disease that can present with hyperkeratosis. Psoriatic arthritis, a related condition, can lead to arthropathy. While atrophic scarring is less typical, systemic inflammation could theoretically contribute to cognitive symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Keratosis Pilaris
diagnoses.description: A common, harmless skin condition causing rough, small bumps, a form of hyperkeratosis. Though typically benign and unrelated to the other symptoms listed, comorbid conditions could account for the broader symptom profile.

diagnoses.name: Pityriasis Rubra Pilaris
diagnoses.description: A rare skin disorder that can present with follicular hyperkeratosis among other symptoms. While typically focusing on skin manifestations, a severe case might indirectly lead to systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Advanced HIV/AIDS can present with a myriad of symptoms including but not limited to skin conditions like hyperkeratosis, atrophic scarring, and various forms of arthropathy. Neurological manifestations can also include delirium.

diagnoses.name: Leprosy
diagnoses.description: A chronic infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae, characterized by skin lesions which can include atrophic scarring and hyperkeratosis. Nerve damage in leprosy can lead to arthropathy, and in severe, untreated cases, delirium might occur due to systemic infection.

diagnoses: Evans syndrome (autoimmune hemolytic anemia with immune thrombocytopenia)

diagnoses.explanation: Chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) is a genetic disorder where white blood cells fail to produce a burst of superoxide to kill certain bacteria and fungi, leading to increased susceptibility to infection, which may present with symptoms similar to pneumonia. Skin infections (like folliculitis) and increased white blood cells, specifically monocytes (monocytosis), are also common.

Hyper IgE Syndrome is an immune disorder characterized by high levels of immunoglobulin E (IgE). Patients may have recurring pneumonia, skin infections such as folliculitis, and an increased susceptibility to infections. Eye complications can include irritation and inflammation.

HIV/AIDS compromises the immune system, leading to an increased susceptibility to infections, including pneumonia. Folliculitis and monocytosis can occur, and eye irritation might be related to various opportunistic infections or inflammation associated with the disease.

Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) can lead to increased susceptibility to infections, including pneumonia, due to a dysfunction in the white blood cells. AML can also cause monocytosis and may indirectly cause skin and eye issues due to the overall impact on the immune system.

Cyclic Neutropenia is a disorder characterized by periodic decreases in neutrophils, leading to increased susceptibility to infections such as pneumonia and skin infections including folliculitis. While this condition primarily impacts neutrophil counts, patients might also experience abnormalities in other white blood cells, including monocytes.

Myelodysplastic syndromes are a group of disorders caused by poorly formed or dysfunctional blood cells. This can lead to an increased risk of infections, monocytosis, and can indirectly cause symptoms like folliculitis due to infection vulnerability and possibly eye irritation due to systemic inflammation.

SCID is a primary immune deficiency characterized by a severe defect in both the T- and B-lymphocyte systems. This leads to increased susceptibility to infections, including pneumonia, and can indirectly cause skin and eye issues due to the lack of immune response.

Leukocyte Adhesion Deficiency is a disorder of the immune system where white blood cells are unable to properly adhere to and migrate towards sites of infection, leading to increased susceptibility to infections, including skin infections like folliculitis and potentially lung infections manifesting as pneumonia.

CVID is an immune system disorder that causes an increased susceptibility to infections, including pneumonia. People with CVID may experience chronic lung disease, and skin manifestations like folliculitis. Monocytosis can be present as a response to chronic infection.

Sjögren's Syndrome primarily affects the glands that produce tears and saliva, causing dry eyes, which might present as irritated eyes. It is an autoimmune disorder and can lead to an increased susceptibility to infections due to immune dysregulation, and skin manifestations like folliculitis.

diagnoses: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS, in the context of infertility)
Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD, for hyperactivity)
Carcinoma (various types, depending on the origin of warts and other signs)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)

diagnoses.name: Chronic Hepatitis
reasoning: Abnormal liver enzymes often suggest some form of liver disease. Chronic Hepatitis can manifest through symptoms like fatigue, and with liver dysfunction, it might indirectly affect hormonal balances, potentially contributing to delayed puberty.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Hepatitis
reasoning: This condition can cause abnormal liver enzymes and fatigue due to the body's immune system attacking liver cells. It may also lead to hormonal imbalances, affecting puberty timing.

diagnoses.name: Primary Biliary Cholangitis
reasoning: This is a chronic disease that can lead to abnormal liver enzymes. The associated fatigue results from the liver's reduced ability to function, and the hormonal imbalances can interfere with puberty.

diagnoses.name: Non-alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease
reasoning: Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease can present with fatigue and abnormal liver enzymes. Its association with metabolic syndrome might also play a role in delayed puberty due to hormonal imbalances.

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
reasoning: While primarily affecting the digestive system, celiac disease can cause fatigue due to malabsorption of nutrients. It can also lead to liver enzyme abnormalities and delayed puberty due to nutritional deficiencies.

diagnoses.name: Lichen Sclerosus
reasoning: This condition primarily affects the genital and anal areas, potentially explaining vulvodynia. It may also be associated indirectly with liver abnormalities and hormonal issues affecting puberty timing due to systemic inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Hemochromatosis
reasoning: Hemochromatosis can cause abnormal liver enzymes due to iron overload in the liver, leading to fatigue. The iron overload can also affect other organs, potentially delaying puberty.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
reasoning: HIV/AIDS can cause a wide range of symptoms including fatigue, abnormal liver enzymes due to medication or the virus itself, and indirectly, delayed puberty through its effects on the body.

diagnoses.name: Wilson's Disease
reasoning: This genetic disorder leads to abnormal copper accumulation in the body, including the liver, causing abnormal liver enzymes. It can also cause fatigue and potentially affect puberty through its systemic effects.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
reasoning: While primarily a disease of the kidneys, chronic kidney disease can present with fatigue and affect liver enzyme tests indirectly. It could also interfere with normal puberty due to hormonal imbalances.

diagnoses.name: Common Variable Immunodeficiency
diagnoses.rationale: Characterized by decreased immunoglobulins, susceptibility to infections (including periodontal disease), and can contribute to autoimmune manifestations that may explain some of the listed symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia
diagnoses.rationale: A genetic disorder that leads to the development of arteriovenous malformations and plethora. While it does not directly explain obsessive-compulsive behavior or decreased immunoglobulins, its systemic impact might contribute to a complex clinical picture.

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.rationale: A blood disorder leading to increased red blood cell mass and plethora. It's associated with a higher risk of blood vessel complications, which might indirectly be connected with arteriovenous malformations. However, it does not directly relate to decreased immunoglobulins or obsessive-compulsive behavior.

diagnoses.name: Von Willebrand Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Though primarily known for bleeding tendencies, it's associated with mucosal bleeding which can exacerbate periodontal disease. It does not directly explain the other symptoms but can have various clinical manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Primary Immunodeficiency Diseases
diagnoses.rationale: A group of disorders characterized by decreased immunoglobulins, leading to an increased susceptibility to infections, including periodontal diseases. Some types may have symptoms or complications that align with the other listed symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Granulomatous Disease
diagnoses.rationale: While primarily affecting phagocytes leading to increased infections (potentially exacerbating periodontal disease), it's a stretch to directly connect it to the rest of the symptoms without further clinical context.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disease can have widespread systemic effects including, but not limited to, decreased immunoglobulins and vascular manifestations. Psychiatric manifestations like obsessive-compulsive behaviors can occur, but the direct relationship with some symptoms like arteriovenous malformations is not clear.

diagnoses.name: Osler-Weber-Rendu Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Another name for Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia, emphasizing the potential for multiple arteriovenous malformations and plethora.

diagnoses.name: Selective IgA Deficiency
diagnoses.rationale: The most common primary immunodeficiency, which could lead to increased infections, including in the oral cavity. Direct connections to obsessive-compulsive behavior or arteriovenous malformations are less clear.

diagnoses.name: Psychogenic Disorders
diagnoses.rationale: While primarily focused on mental health conditions potentially explaining obsessive-compulsive behavior, a comprehensive approach could uncover how stress or psychiatric conditions indirectly affect or exacerbate other physical health issues, like immune system functioning or potentially influencing behaviors that impact periodontal health.

diagnoses: Bacterial Infections (e.g., Salmonella, E. coli, Shigella)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn’s Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death, causing symptoms such as weakness, headache, and aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a minibar, a TIA presents similar to a stroke, including aphasia and weakness, but usually resolves within a few minutes to hours without permanent damage.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A growth of cells within the brain that can cause pressure and symptoms like headache, weakness, and language difficulties.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of migraine that can include visual disturbances and symptoms such as aphasia and weakness before the headache begins.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that affects the brain and spinal cord, leading to symptoms like weakness, coordination problems, and sometimes language difficulties.

diagnoses.name: Intracerebral Hemorrhage
diagnoses.description: Bleeding within the brain tissue itself, which can cause sudden headache, weakness, and difficulty with speech.

diagnoses.name: Subarachnoid Hemorrhage
diagnoses.description: Bleeding in the space between the brain and the tissues covering the brain, often causing a sudden, severe headache, along with weakness and speech issues.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A neurological disorder marked by sudden recurrent episodes of sensory disturbance, sometimes including loss of consciousness or convulsive movements. It can also lead to postictal aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the brain, often caused by a viral infection, leading to symptoms including headache, weakness, confusion, and aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the membranes surrounding the brain and spinal cord, presenting with headache, fever, and in severe cases, symptoms like weakness and difficulty speaking.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition characterized by intense headaches often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound. In some cases, migraine can also lead to aura, which might explain symptoms of parasthesia.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A medical condition that occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Symptoms can include headache, weakness, numbness or paralysis, and difficulty speaking or understanding speech.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in the brain. Symptoms can vary widely but may include headache, vomiting, weakness, and changes in sensation (like parasthesia), depending on the tumor's location.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease in which the body's immune system attacks its tissues, specifically the myelin sheath, which leads to demyelination and affects the transmission of nerve signals. Symptoms can include parasthesia, weakness, and in some cases, vomiting and headache.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which the body's immune system attacks the peripheral nerves. Initial symptoms can include weakness and tingling in the extremities. As the condition progresses, these symptoms can increase in intensity, leading to severe weakness and, in some cases, other symptoms such as vomiting.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the brain and spinal cord membranes, typically caused by an infection. The inflammation can lead to symptoms like headache, vomiting, weakness, and altered sensation (including parasthesia).

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the brain, caused by an infection or an autoimmune response. Symptoms can include headache, fever, vomiting, weakness, confusion, and sensory disturbances such as parasthesia.

diagnoses.name: Hypoglycemia
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by an abnormally low level of blood sugar (glucose), which can lead to symptoms such as weakness, headache, vomiting, and in severe cases, seizures or unconsciousness. People with diabetes are particularly at risk.

diagnoses.name: Electrolyte Imbalance
diagnoses.description: An imbalance in the levels of minerals in the body essential for muscle contraction, nerve signaling, and water balance. Symptoms can include headache, weakness, vomiting, and tingling or numbness (parasthesia).

diagnoses.name: Vertebral Artery Dissection
diagnoses.description: A tear in the lining of a vertebral artery, which can lead to a stroke. It can manifest with symptoms such as headache, neck pain, vomiting, weakness, and numbness or tingling (parasthesia), especially in the head and neck region.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic illness involving your central nervous system. The immune system attacks myelin, which is the protective layer around your nerve fibers, leading to delayed response or permanent nerve damage.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: Migraines that are preceded or accompanied by sensory disturbances called aura. These disturbances can include flashes of light, blind spots, and other vision changes or tingling in your hand or face.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: Occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes. Symptoms can include sudden numbness, confusion, trouble seeing, walking, and a severe headache.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a ministroke, a TIA is a brief period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke but usually lasting only a few minutes and causing no permanent damage. Often a warning sign for a future stroke.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which your body's immune system attacks your nerves. Weakness and tingling in your extremities are usually the first symptoms. These sensations can quickly spread, eventually paralyzing your whole body.

diagnoses.name: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)
diagnoses.description: Also known as Lou Gehrig's disease, it's a progressive nervous system disease that affects nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord, causing loss of muscle control.

diagnoses.name: Myasthenia Gravis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disorder in which antibodies destroy the communication between nerves and muscle, resulting in weakness of the skeletal muscles.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A brain tumor can be either non-cancerous (benign) or cancerous (malignant), primary, or secondary. Symptoms can include headaches, changes in speech or hearing, and neurological problems.

diagnoses.name: Vertebrobasilar Circulatory Disorders
diagnoses.description: Conditions that occur when blood flow to the back region of the brain is disrupted. Symptoms can include dizziness, dysphagia, double vision, and numbness.

diagnoses.name: Multiple System Atrophy
diagnoses.description: A rare, degenerative neurological disorder affecting your body's involuntary functions, including blood pressure, breathing, bladder function, and motor control.

diagnoses: Hepatitis B or C associated cryoglobulinemia
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS Syndrome)
Evans Syndrome (autoimmune hemolytic anemia with immune thrombocytopenia)
Hepatitis B or C (with associated cryoglobulinemia)
